metadata.title: Piper PA-46
aws::graph::propositions: Piper PA-46-500TP Malibu Meridian Development and Specifications
Piper announced its intention to market a turboprop-powered version of the Malibu in 1997.
Piper flew a prototype of the turboprop-powered Malibu in 1998.
The prototype was powered by a Pratt & Whitney Canada PT6A-42A engine.
The Pratt & Whitney Canada PT6A-42A engine produces 500 shp (370 kW).
Certification for the PA-46-500TP Malibu Meridian was achieved in September 2000.
Deliveries of the PA-46-500TP Malibu Meridian began in November 2000.
Changes made to the PA-46-500TP Malibu Meridian include larger wings compared to the Malibu.
Changes made to the PA-46-500TP Malibu Meridian include larger tail surfaces compared to the Malibu.
In 2009, Piper began offering the Meridian with a three-screen version of the Garmin G1000.
The Garmin G1000 system included the Garmin GFC 700 autopilot.
The Garmin G1000 system replaced the Avidyne Entegra system in the Meridian.
Piper added wing root filets to the PA-46-500TP Malibu Meridian to increase wing area.
Piper added 342 lb (155 kg) of fuel capacity to the PA-46-500TP Malibu Meridian.
Piper added a larger tailplane to the PA-46-500TP Malibu Meridian.
Piper reinforced the wing spar of the PA-46-500TP Malibu Meridian.
Piper reinforced the landing gear of the PA-46-500TP Malibu Meridian.
The modifications raised the Maximum Take-Off Weight (MTOW) to 4,850 lb (2,200 kg).
From 2003, the Maximum Take-Off Weight (MTOW) was increased to 5,092 lb (2,310 kg).

text:
### PA-46-500TP Malibu Meridian

In 1997, Piper announced its intention to market a turboprop-powered version of the Malibu, and flew a prototype the following year powered by a Pratt & Whitney Canada PT6A-42A of 500 shp (370 kW). Certification was achieved in September 2000 and deliveries began in November that year. Changes made to allow for turboprop power include larger wings and tail surfaces. In 2009, Piper began offering the Meridian with a three-screen version of the Garmin G1000 including the Garmin GFC 700 autopilot as a replacement for the Avidyne Entegra system.
Piper added wing root filets to increase wing area and 342 lb (155 kg) of fuel capacity, a larger tailplane and reinforced wing spar and landing gear to raise MTOW to 4,850 lb (2,200 kg) then 5,092 lb (2,310 kg) from 2003.
